question: What is the fundamental concept of the GMDSS?

answers.a: a) It is intended to automate and improve emergency communications in the maritime industry.
answers.b: b) It is intended to automate and improve existing digital selective calling procedures and techniques.
answers.c: c) It is intended to provide more effective but lower cost commercial communications.
answers.d: d) It is intended to provide compulsory vessels with a collision avoidance system when they are operating in waters that are also occupied by non-compulsory vessels.

question: The primary purpose of the GMDSS is?

answers.a: a) Allow more effective control of SAR situations by vessels.
answers.b: b) Provide additional shipboard systems for more effective company communications.
answers.c: c) Automate and improve emergency communications for the world's shipping industry.

question: What is the basic concept of GMDSS?

answers.a: a) Search and rescue authorities ashore can be alerted to a Distress situation.
answers.b: b) Shipping in the immediate vicinity of a ship in Distress will be rapidly alerted.
answers.c: c) Shoreside authorities and vessels can assist in a coordinated SAR operation with minimum delay.

question: GMDSS is primarily a system based on?

answers.a: a) Ship-to-ship Distress communications using MF or HF radiotelephony.
answers.b: b) VHF digital selective calling from ship to shore.
answers.c: c) Distress, Urgency and safety communications carried out by the use of narrow-band direct printing telegraphy.
answers.d: d) The linking of search and rescue authorities ashore with shipping in the immediate vicinity of a ship in Distress or in need of assistance.

question: What is the responsibility of vessels under GMDSS?

answers.a: a) Vessels over 300 gross tons may be required to render assistance if such assistance does not adversely affect their port schedule.
answers.b: b) Only that vessel, regardless of size, closest to a vessel in Distress, is required to render assistance.
answers.c: c) Every ship is able to perform those communications functions that are essential for the safety of the ship itself and of other ships.
answers.d: d) Vessels operating under GMDSS, outside of areas effectively serviced by shoreside authorities, operating in sea areas A2, and A4 may be required to render assistance in Distress situations.

question: GMDSS is required for which of the following?

answers.a: a) All vessels capable of international voyages.
answers.b: b) Vessels operating outside of the range of VHF coastal radio stations.
answers.c: c) SOLAS Convention ships of 300 gross tonnage or more.
answers.d: d) Coastal vessels of less than 300 gross tons.

question: by the International Maritime Organization?

answers.a: a) Radio Direction Finding.
answers.b: b) Distress alerting to and from vessels, search and rescue coordination, on-scene communications, signals for locating, Maritime Safety Information, general and bridge-to-bridge communications.
answers.c: c) Communications in each of the operational ocean areas.
answers.d: d) All communications possible within the International Safety-Net service.

answers.b: b) A3

question: Within a single sea area, what is the primary reason GMDSS imposes carriage requirements for different radio subsystems?

answers.a: a) Redundancy in duplicating all operational functions in the event of a system failure.
answers.b: b) Each subsystem has a specific purpose and capabilities that generally cannot be duplicated by other subsystems.
answers.c: c) Different radio systems may be used by the various authorities.
answers.d: d) The ability to communicate in all modes with any of the shore stations.

question: If operating within Ocean Area A1, and outside of NAVTEX coverage, a GMDSS-equipped vessel must carry?

answers.b: b) A GPS receiver
answers.c: c) Equipment capable of maintaining a continuous DSC watch on 2187.5 kHz.
answers.d: d) Equipment capable of reception of Maritime Safety Information by the Inmarsat enhanced group call system, or HF NBDP.

question: What is the equipment carriage requirement for survival craft under GMDSS?

answers.a: a) At least three approved two-way VHF radiotelephones on every passenger ship and cargo ships of 500 gross tons and upwards.
answers.b: b) At least two approved two-way VHF radiotelephones on every cargo ship between 300-500 gross tons.
answers.c: c) At least one radar transponder must be carried on every cargo ship of 300-500 gross tons and two transponders (one for each side) of every passenger ship and every cargo ship of 500 gross tons and upward.

question: Which of the following statements concerning maintenance requirements is false?

answers.a: a) Compulsory vessels sailing in Sea Areas A1 and A2 must provide any one of the three maintenance options which are duplication of equipment, shore-based, or at-sea maintenance capability.
answers.b: b) Compulsory vessels sailing in Sea Areas A3 and A4 must provide any two of the three maintenance options which are duplication of equipment, shore-based, or at-sea maintenance capability.
answers.c: c) If shore-based maintenance is used, maintenance services do not have to be completed or performance verified unless the vessel will be sailing to a non-US port.
answers.d: d) Equipment warranties do not satisfy GMDSS maintenance requirements.

question: Which of the following statements concerning maintenance requirements is true?

answers.a: a) The options are duplication of equipment, at-sea maintenance, and shore-based maintenance.
answers.b: b) Compulsory vessels between 300-500 gross tons are required only to provide one maintenance option, while compulsory vessels larger than 500 gross tons and all passenger vessels are required to provide any two of the three maintenance options.
answers.c: c) The ""at-sea"" maintenance may be waived if the compulsory vessel carries at least three licensed GMDSS Radio Operators.
answers.d: d) Compulsory vessels operating in Sea Area A4 are required to carry at least one licensed GMDSS Radio Maintainer.

question: Which of the following is a requirement, under GMDSS, for all vessels over 300 gross tons operating within range of a MF-DSC equipped shore station?

answers.d: d) Only one of the three maintenance options is required.

question: Which of the following maintenance functions is not the responsibility of the GMDSS Radio Operator?

question: When may a compulsory vessel not be allowed to leave port?

answers.a: a) When the vessel is in an over-carriage condition.
answers.b: b) When the vessel has arranged for both duplication of equipment AND shore-based maintenance.
answers.c: c) When the vessel has replaced a required piece of GMDSS-related equipment but its performance has not been verified or logged.
answers.d: d) When the vessel is carrying only two licensed GMDSS Radio Operators and is capable of performing all required functions.

question: Which statement is false regarding the maintenance of GMDSS equipment at sea?

answers.a: a) The GMDSS maintainer may not be the person designated to have primary responsibility for radio-communications during Distress incidents even if licensed as an operator.
answers.b: b) Ships must carry at least one person who qualifies as a GMDSS maintainer for the maintenance and repair of equipment if the at-sea maintenance option is selected.
answers.c: c) All at-sea maintenance and repairs must be performed by, or under the supervision of a person holding a GMDSS Maintainer license.
answers.d: d) The GMDSS maintainer may be the person responsible for ensuring that the watches are properly maintained and that the proper guard channels and the vessel's position are entered into the DSC equipment.

question: Which of the following service or maintenance functions may NOT be performed by the holder of a GMDSS Radio Operator License?

answers.a: a) Reset tripped circuit breakers or replace defective fuses.
answers.b: b) Routine battery maintenance if used as part of the GMDSS station.
answers.c: c) Any adjustments or maintenance that may affect the proper operation of the station.
answers.d: d) Replacement of consumable items such as paper, ribbons, etc.

question: What are the conditions, under GMDSS, whereby a ship is NOT allowed to depart from any port?

answers.b: b) The vessel is carrying more than the required number of qualified GMDSS radio operators.
answers.c: c) The vessel has a temporary waiver of its radio license and Safety Certificate.
answers.d: d) The vessel is not carrying a GMDSS radio maintainer, but has provided for shoreside maintenance plus duplication of equipment if required.

question: What determines the spares and maintenance materials requirements for the SITOR equipment under GMDSS?

answers.a: a) The recommendations of the manufacturer.
answers.b: b) 47 CFR Part 80
answers.c: c) IMO Circular ""Equipment Spares"".

question: Which of the following is the minimum license requirement of a GMDSS Radio Operator?

answers.a: a) Holding the Marine Radio Operator Permit is a pre-requisite before the GMDSS Radio Operator Endorsement can be obtained.
answers.b: b) Holding the General Radiotelephone Operator License with RADAR endorsement is sufficient.
answers.c: c) Holding a valid GMDSS Radio Operator license is sufficient.
answers.d: d) Holding either the General Radiotelephone Operator License or the First or Second Class Radiotelegraph license with GMDSS Radio Maintainer's endorsement is sufficient.

question: Which of the following statements concerning GMDSS Radio Operator requirements is false?

answers.a: a) Each compulsory vessel must carry at least two licensed GMDSS Radio Operators at all times while at sea.
answers.b: b) Each compulsory vessel must carry at least two licensed GMDSS Radio Operators at all times while at sea and may elect to carry a GMDSS Radio Maintainer as well.
answers.c: c) Communications involving Safety of life at sea do not have to be logged as long as the compulsory vessel was not involved in such communications.
answers.d: d) While at sea, adjustments to, and the maintaining of, GMDSS equipment may be performed by the GMDSS Radio Operator as long as the work is supervised by an on-board licensed GMDSS Radio Maintainer.

question: What is the minimum operator license required to perform or supervise the performance of at-sea adjustments, servicing or maintenance which may affect the proper operation of the GMDSS station?

answers.b: b) General Radiotelephone Operator license and Radar endorsement.
answers.c: c) Designated maintainer possessing a GMDSS Radio Operator license.

question: Which statement is false regarding the radio operator requirements for a GMDSS-equipped ship station?

answers.a: a) One of the qualified GMDSS radio operators must be designated to have primary responsibility for radio-communications during Distress incidents.
answers.b: b) A qualified GMDSS radio operator, and a qualified backup, must be designated to perform Distress, Urgency and Safety communications.
answers.c: c) Maintaining a record of all incidents connected with the radio-communications service that appear to be of importance to safety of life at sea is not required.
answers.d: d) While at sea, all adjustments or radio installations, servicing or maintenance of such installations that may affect the proper operation of the GMDSS station must be performed by, or under the supervision of, a qualified GMDSS radio maintainer.

question: What are the vessel equipment and personnel requirements of GMDSS?

answers.a: a) Two licensed GMDSS radio operators.
answers.b: b) Equipment carriage requirements.
answers.c: c) Distress alerting and response.

question: What is the minimum requirement of a GMDSS radio operator?

answers.a: a) Marine Radio Operator Permit and GMDSS Endorsement.
answers.b: b) General Radiotelephone Operator license and Radar endorsement.
answers.c: c) GMDSS Radio Operator license.
answers.d: d) General Radiotelephone license or First or Second Class Radiotelegraph license with GMDSS Radio Maintainer's endorsement.

question: Which statement is false regarding the GMDSS requirement for ship sources of energy?

answers.a: a) At all times while the vessel is at sea, a sufficient supply of electrical energy to operate the radio installations and charge any batteries which may be part of the reserve source of energy is required.
answers.b: b) The reserve sources of energy need to supply independent MF and HF radio installations at the same time.
answers.c: c) An uninterruptible power supply or other means of ensuring a continuous supply of electrical power to all GMDSS equipment that could be affected by normal variations and interruptions of ship's power is required.
answers.d: d) If an uninterrupted vessel position is required for the proper performance of a GMDSS console -- a means must be provided to ensure this happens in the event of failure of the main or emergency source of energy.

question: What is the meaning of "Reserve Source of Energy"?

answers.a: a) The supply of electrical energy sufficient to operate the radio installations for the purpose of conducting Distress and Safety communications in the event of failure of the ship's main and emergency sources of electrical power.
answers.b: b) High caloric value items for lifeboat, per SOLAS regulations.
answers.c: c) Diesel fuel stored for the purpose of operating the powered survival craft for a period equal to or exceeding the U.S.C.G. and SOLAS requirements.

question: In the event of failure of the main and emergency sources of electrical power -- what is the term for the source required to supply the GMDSS console with power for conducting distress and other radio-communications?

answers.a: a) Emergency power
answers.b: b) Reserve source of energy
answers.c: c) Ship's emergency diesel generator

question: What are the characteristics of the Reserve Source of Energy under GMDSS?

answers.a: a) Supplies independent HF and MF installations at the same time.
answers.b: b) Cannot be independent of the propelling power of the ship.
answers.c: c) Must be incorporated into the ship's electrical system.
answers.d: d) Must be independent of the ship's electrical system when the RSE is needed to supply power to the GMDSS equipment.

question: What is the requirement for emergency and reserve power in GMDSS radio installations?

answers.a: a) An emergency power source for radio communications is not required if a vessel has proper reserve power (batteries).
answers.b: b) A reserve power source is not required for radio communications.
answers.c: c) Only one of the above is required if a vessel is equipped with a second 406 EPIRB as a backup means of sending a Distress alert.
answers.d: d) All newly constructed ships under GMDSS must have both emergency and reserve power sources for radio communications.

question: Which of the following terms is defined as a back-up power source that provides power to radio installations for the purpose of conducting Distress and Safety communications when the vessel's main and emergency generators cannot?

answers.a: a) Reserve Source of Energy (RSE)
answers.b: b) Emergency Diesel Generator (EDG)
answers.c: c) Reserve Source of Diesel Power (RSDP)

question: Under GMDSS, a compulsory VHF-DSC radiotelephone installation must be tested at what minimum intervals at sea?

answers.a: a) Daily
answers.b: b) Annually, by a representative of the FCC.
answers.c: c) At the annual SOLAS inspection.

question: Testing of a compulsory radiotelephone station should be done?

answers.a: a) Into an artificial antenna.
answers.b: b) May be accomplished by using the radiotelephone for normal business.
answers.c: c) On 2182 kHz and must be heard clearly under normal conditions at a range of 150 nautical miles.

question: While underway, how frequently is the DSC controller required to be tested?

answers.a: a) Once a day
answers.b: b) Once a week
answers.c: c) Twice a week

question: At sea, all required equipment (other than Survival Craft Equipment) must be proven operational by?

answers.a: a) Daily testing
answers.b: b) By either a) or c)
answers.c: c) Operational use of the equipment.
answers.d: d) Testing at least every 48 hours.

question: The best way to test the MF-HF NBDP system is?

answers.a: a) Make a radiotelephone call to a coast station.
answers.b: b) Initiate an ARQ call to demonstrate that the transmitter and antenna are working.
answers.c: c) Initiate an FEC call to demonstrate that the transmitter and antenna are working.
answers.d: d) Initiate an ARQ call to a Coast Station and wait for the automatic exchange of answerbacks.

question: The best way to test the Inmarsat-C terminal is?

answers.a: a) Send a message to a shore terminal and wait for confirmation.
answers.b: b) Compose and send a brief message to your own Inmarsat-C terminal.
answers.c: c) Send a message to another ship terminal.
answers.d: d) If the "Send" light flashes, proper operation has been confirmed.

question: A vessel certified for service in Sea Area A3 is required to maintain a watch on?

answers.b: b) MF Frequency 2187.5

question: A vessel certified for service in Sea Area A-2 is required to maintain watch on?

answers.c: c) 8 MHz HF DSC, 1 other HF DSC, 2 MHz MF DSC and VHF Ch-70.

question: Proper watchkeeping includes the following:

answers.a: a) All required frequencies are being monitored in the proper mode.

question: Proper watchkeeping includes the following:

answers.a: a) Understanding the GMDSS console's normal operational indicators.

question: Which is true concerning a required watch on VHF Ch-16.

answers.a: a) It is compulsory at all times while at sea until further notice, unless the vessel is in a VTS system.
answers.b: b) When a vessel is in an A1 sea area and subject to the Bridge-to-Bridge act and in a VTS system, a watch is not required on Ch-16 provided the vessel monitors both Ch-13 and VTS channel.
answers.c: c) It is always compulsory in sea areas A2, A3 and A4.

question: Which of the following statements are true?

answers.a: a) GMDSS Radio Logs are required to contain entries pertaining to all incidents connected with the radio-communications service that appear to be of importance to the safety of life at sea.
answers.b: b) All Distress communications must be entered in the GMDSS radio log.

question: Which of the following statements are true?

answers.a: a) Key letters or abbreviations may not be used in GMDSS Radio Logbooks under any circumstances.

question: Where should the GMDSS radio log be kept on board ship?

answers.a: a) Captain's office
answers.b: b) Sea cabin
answers.c: c) At the GMDSS operating position.
answers.d: d) Anywhere on board the vessel.

question: How long must the radio log be retained on board before sending it to the shoreside licensee?

question: How long must the radio log be archived by the licensee?

answers.c: c) Both of the above

question: Which of the following logkeeping statements is true?

question: DSC transmissions are encoded:

answers.a: a) J3E/H3E TELEX emissions
answers.b: b) F1B/J2B voice emissions

question: Which of the following statements concerning DSC equipment is true?

answers.a: a) The GMDSS Radio Operator is responsible for properly selecting HF DSC guard channels.
answers.b: b) All equipment must be type accepted.
answers.c: c) The vessel's navigational position must be updated, either automatically or manually, no less often that every four (4) hours.

question: What is the action that a GMDSS Radio Operator should take when a DSC Distress alert is received?

answers.a: a) No action is necessary, as the DSC control unit will automatically switch to the NBDP follow-on communications frequency.
answers.b: b) The Operator should immediately set continuous watch on the radiotelephone frequency that is associated with frequency band on which the Distress alert was received.
answers.c: c) The Operator should immediately set continuous watch on VHF channel 70.
answers.d: d) The Operator should immediately set continuous watch on the NBDP frequency that is associated with frequency band on which the Distress alert was received.

question: What does the DSC control unit do if the GMDSS Radio Operator fails to insert updated information when initiating a DSC Distress alert?

answers.a: a) It will abort the transmission and set off an audible alarm that must be manually reset.
answers.b: b) It will initiate the DSC Distress alert but, as no information will be transmitted, rescue personnel will not be able to identify the vessel, its position, or its situation.
answers.c: c) It will initiate the DSC Distress alert, and default information will automatically be transmitted.
answers.d: d) It will initiate the DSC Distress alert, but any station receiving it will have to establish contact with the Distressed vessel to determine its identity, position, and situation.

question: A DSC Distress alert:

answers.a: a) Must always be sent on VHF Ch-70.
answers.b: b) Must always be sent on MF 2 MHz plus one other HF DSC frequency.
answers.c: c) Will always be sent on one or more of the DSC Distress frequencies.
answers.d: d) Must always be sent on VHF Ch-70, then 2 MHz MF then 8 MHz HF.

question: In all cases, the transmit frequency of a MF/HF console DSC Distress alert:

answers.c: c) It depends upon operator DSC Call set up entries.

question: DSC relays of Distress Alerts by vessels:

answers.b: b) Should be transmitted to ships involved in Distress traffic.
answers.c: c) Should be avoided, however after repeated alerts, should be relayed to a Coast Station nearest the Distress incident.
answers.d: d) Are the best means to provide for a relay of Distress communications.

question: Which of the following is not a DSC watch frequency?

answers.b: b) 6312 kHz
answers.c: c) 2182 kHz

question: Which of the following channels and modes should be used when initiating a Distress alert transmission?

question: How many total frequencies are available for DSC Distress alerting?

answers.c: c) Five

question: Which of the following are the MF/HF DSC Distress watch frequencies

answers.a: a) By dialing the correct code on the telephone remote unit.

answers.c: c) By contacting the CES operator and announcing a Distress condition is in existence.
answers.d: d) By contacting the CES operator using the radiotelephone Distress procedure ""Mayday""... etc.

question: Which of the following statements is true regarding Distress alerting under GMDSS?

answers.a: a) The Distress alert should identify the station in Distress and its position & time of position update. Also, the alert may include the nature of the Distress, the type of assistance required, or the course and speed of the mobile unit.
answers.b: b) Ship to shore Distress alerts are used to alert other ships in port of navigational hazards.
answers.c: c) Ship-to-ship Distress alerts are used to alert other ships in the vicinity of navigational hazards and bad weather.
answers.d: d) The vessel nearest to the emergency must notify the Coast Guard before leaving the vicinity.

question: If a GMDSS Radio Operator initiates a DSC Distress transmission but does not insert a message, what happens?

answers.a: a) The transmission is aborted and an alarm sounds to indicate this data must be provided by the operator.
answers.b: b) The transmission is not initiated and ""ERROR"" is indicated on the display readout.
answers.c: c) The transmission will be made with ""default"" information provided automatically.
answers.d: d) The receiving station will poll the DSC unit of the vessel in Distress to download the necessary information.

question: Repetition of a DSC Distress call is normally automatic if not acknowledged after a delay of:

answers.a: a) 1 - 2 minutes
answers.b: b) 2 - 5 minutes
answers.c: c) 3.5 - 4.5 minutes

question: A MF/HF DSC Distress call:

answers.a: a) Will send the minimal necessary information using the ""Distress Button"" or ""Distress Hot Key""
answers.b: b) Contains all the information normally of interest in on-scene Distress communications.
answers.c: c) Will send a more detailed Distress format if time permits and operator data entries are correctly performed.
answers.d: d) Both a) and c) are true

question: KEYTOPIC #030: FOLLOW-ON VOICE TRANSMISSION:

answers.a: a) Follow on communications should be presumed to take place on the TELEX frequency associated with the specific DSC frequency used.
answers.b: b) Follow on communications should be presumed to take place on the voice frequency associated with the specific DSC frequency used.
answers.c: c) An alternate emission and frequency may be specified for follow-up communications by the vessel originating the Distress Alert.
answers.d: d) Both b) and c) are true

question: You send a VHF-DSC Distress alert. What channel do you use for the follow-on voice transmission?

answers.a: a) Ch-12
answers.b: b) Ch-70
answers.c: c) Ch-13

question: You send a MF-DSC Distress alert. What frequency do you use for the follow-on voice transmission?

answers.a: a) 2760 kHz
answers.c: c) 2182 kHz

question: You send a HF-DSC alert on 8414.5 kHz. What frequency do you use for the voice transmission?

answers.a: a) All Ships 3x, this is Ship's Name/Call Sign 3x ,Mayday, Position.
answers.b: b) Mayday 3x, this is Ship's Name/Call Sign 3x, Distress category.
answers.c: c) Both of the above.

question: What information should be included in a Distress follow on voice transmission?

answers.a: a) Ship's Name and Call Sign.
answers.b: b) Ship's position.
answers.c: c) Ship's MMSI number.

question: What information should be included in a Distress follow on voice transmission?

answers.a: a) Follow on working frequency.
answers.b: b) ETA at next port.
answers.c: c) None of the above.

question: Which statement is true regarding the receipt and acknowledgement of actual Distress follow-on communications by GMDSS ship stations.

answers.a: a) A ship station that receives a Distress call from another vessel must, as soon as possible, inform the Master or person responsible for the ship of the contents of the Distress communications received.
answers.b: b) Ship stations in receipt of distress alert should not defer acknowledgement for a short interval, so that receipt may be acknowledged by the coast station.
answers.c: c) A Coast station has the sole obligation to respond.  A ship station should wait for the Coast station MMSI DSC Acknowledgment before taking action. If a Coast station has no response in 15 minutes the ship should DSC acknowledge and inform the RCC.
answers.d: d) Alerts concerning navigational hazards are second only to safety traffic.

question: What does the acronym EOS indicate in the received message?

answers.a: a) Error Of Sequence
answers.b: b) End Of Sequence
answers.c: c) End Of Signals

question: What is the proper procedure to be followed upon receipt of a Distress alert transmitted by use of Digital Selective Calling techniques?

answers.a: a) Set watch on the DSC alerting frequency in the band of frequencies the alert was received.
answers.b: b) Set watch on the radiotelephone Distress and Safety frequency associated with the Distress and Safety calling frequency on which the Distress alert was received.
answers.c: c) Set a continuous watch on VHF-FM Channel 13, 16 and DSC on Channel 70.
answers.d: d) Ship stations equipped with narrow-band direct-printing equipment should respond to the Distress alert as soon as practicable by this means.

question: What does the acronym ECC indicate in the received message?

answers.a: a) Every Cipher Counted
answers.b: b) Error Cannot Confirm
answers.c: c) Error Check Character

question: What action should be taken on receipt of a Distress alert?

answers.a: a) Read the display screen and/or printout.
answers.b: b) Silence the alarm.
answers.c: c) Listen for any follow on voice/TELEX transmission on the appropriate frequency.

question: What action should be taken if a Distress alert is received on the 12 MHz DSC frequency?

answers.a: a) Use DSC to acknowledge the alert using the 12 MHz DSC frequency.
answers.b: b) Set the receiver to 12290.0 kHz J3E.
answers.c: c) Do nothing. Ship is too far away to render assistance.
answers.d: d) Set the receiver to 12520.0 kHz F1B.

question: Your ship received a Distress relay from the U.S. Coast Guard on DSC freq. 2187.5 kHz. You would acknowledge by radiotelephony on what frequency?

answers.a: a) Ch-70
answers.b: b) Ch-06
answers.c: c) Ch-13

question: Under what conditions would you relay a DSC Distress alert?

answers.a: a) If the mobile unit in Distress is incapable of further Distress Alert communications.
answers.b: b) If no Coast Station/Mobile Unit acknowledgement is observed.
answers.c: c) Answers a) and b) are both possible.
answers.d: d) You should never relay such an alert -- the Coast Station & RCC will do that.

question: The relay of DSC Distress Alerts:

answers.a: a) Has completely overburdened the GMDSS system with improperly formatted or inappropriately relayed DSC calls.
answers.b: b) Was originally an intended function of the GMDSS system.
answers.c: c) Is no longer the preferred method for passing Distress message traffic to an RCC or Coast Station.

question: Transmission of a Distress alert by a station not in itself in Distress should occur:

answers.a: a) When the mobile unit actually in Distress is not itself in a position to transmit the Distress alert.
answers.b: b) When the Master or responsible person on the mobile unit not in Distress so decides.
answers.c: c) When the responsible person at the Coast Station determines further help is necessary.
answers.d: d) In some cases, all of the preceding situations may justify a Distress Alert relay.

question: Relays of Distress Alerts using DSC may still be done.  However, it is now recommended that such relays be done:

answers.a: a) Only by Inmarsat-C TELEX with Distress Priority.
answers.b: b) Only by Inmarsat-B voice or TELEX with Distress priority.
answers.c: c) Preferably by MF/HF voice or TELEX directly to the RCC.
answers.d: d) By any of the above methods which will effectively provide Distress communications to an RCC or Coast station without further activations of other Mobile Units' DSC controllers.

question: What action should you take after sending a false Distress alert on VHF?

answers.a: a) Send a DSC cancellation message on Ch-70.
answers.b: b) Make a voice announcement to cancel the alert on Ch-16.
answers.c: c) Make a voice announcement to cancel the alert on Ch-13.
answers.d: d) Make a voice announcement to cancel the alert on Ch-22A.

question: What action should you take after sending a false Distress alert on MF?

answers.a: a) Make a voice announcement to cancel the alert on 2187.5 kHz.
answers.b: b) Make a voice announcement to cancel the alert on 2174.5 kHz.
answers.c: c) Make a voice announcement to cancel the alert on 2182.0 kHz.
answers.d: d) Send another DSC alert and follow on with voice on 2182.0 kHz.

question: What action should you take after sending a false Distress alert on MF?

answers.b: b) No action is necessary.
answers.c: c) Send a DSC alert on all 7 DSC frequencies and follow on voice on 2174.5 kHz.
answers.d: d) Make a voice announcement to cancel the alert on 2182.0 kHz.

question: What action should you take after sending a false Distress alert on 8 MHz?

answers.d: d) Make an ""Urgency"" call on 8614.0 kHz canceling the alert.

question: What action should you take after sending a false Distress alert on 12577.0 kHz?

question: What action should you take after sending a false Distress alert on Inmarsat-C?

question: What is the fundamental purpose for imposing radio silence?

answers.a: a) To ensure that interference to proprietary communications is minimized.
answers.b: b) To ensure that only voice communications can be effected on the Distress frequency or channel.
answers.c: c) To ensure that a Distressed vessel will have a ""window"" twice each hour for transmitting routine messages.
answers.d: d) To ensure that interference on a particular frequency or channel for communications concerning emergency traffic is minimized.

question: When can routine communications be resumed when radio silence has been imposed?

answers.a: a) After determining that the frequency or channel appears to be no longer in use.
answers.b: b) After determining that geographic distance from the Distress situation will prohibit any other signal from interfering with emergency communications.
answers.c: c) Routine communications can resume after the Rescue Coordination Center transmits a message on the frequency or channel being used for emergency communications stating that such traffic has concluded.
answers.d: d) If, in the master's opinion, communications on that frequency will interfere with emergency communications.

question: What is meant by the term ""radio silence""?

answers.a: a) Stations not directly involved with the on-going Distress communications may not transmit on the Distress frequency or channel.
answers.b: b) Stations remaining off the air to safeguard proprietary information.
answers.c: c) Two three-minute silent periods, at 15 and 45 minutes after the hour, that  provide a transmitting ""window"" for Distressed vessels to transmit Distress alerts using J3E.
answers.d: d) Communications on a Distress frequency or channel is banned for 24 hours following the cessation of the Distress traffic.

question: How is ""radio silence"" imposed?

answers.a: a) By the On Scene Coordinator (OSC).
answers.b: b) By the Coast Earth Station (CES) controlling the Distress communications on that frequency.
answers.c: c) By the nearest Public Correspondence Coast Station.
answers.d: d) By the vessel first responding to the Distress call.

question: How are normal working conditions restored on a narrow band direct printing (NBDP) frequency on which radio silence had been imposed?

answers.a: a) The RCC that imposed the radio silence must transmit a NBDP message stating ""SILENCE FINI"".
answers.b: b) The CES that imposed the radio silence must transmit a NBDP message stating ""SILENCE FINI"".
answers.c: c) The Public Correspondence Station (PCS) that imposed the radio silence must transmit a narrow band direct printing message on the Distress frequency stating ""SILENCE FINI"".
answers.d: d) The High Seas Service (HSS) that imposed the radio silence must transmit a narrow band direct printing message on the Distress frequency stating ""SILENCE FINI"".

question: How are normal working conditions restored after radio silence has been imposed?

answers.a: a) The Rescue Coordination Center (RCC) that imposed the radio silence must transmit a voice message on the Distress frequency stating ""SEELONCE FEENEE"".
answers.b: b) The Coast Earth Station (CES) that imposed the radio silence must transmit a voice message on the Distress frequency stating ""SILENCE FINI"".
answers.c: c) The Public Correspondence Station (PCS) that imposed the radio silence must transmit a voice message on the Distress frequency stating ""SILENCE FINI"".

question: What does a SART signal sound or look like?

answers.b: b) It will appear on a radar unit's PPI as a line of dots radiating outward, with the innermost dot indicating the SART's position.

question: How can rescue personnel detect that a SART is transmitting in the immediate vicinity?

answers.c: c) The SART can provide an approximate location to within a two nautical mile radius, per IMO standards.

question: What signal is detected as originating from an SART?

question: How are high seas (HF) radiotelephone communications initially established between a vessel and a public correspondence station?

question: What is the best procedure for calling another ship station using HF radiotelephone when the signals are weak but readable?

answers.a: a) On a properly selected ITU channel, give the call sign of the ship being called three times using the ICAO alphabet, then ""this is"" followed by the call sign of the ship initiating the call three times, using the ICAO alphabet, and ending with ""over.""
answers.b: b) Give the name of the ship being called three times, and the words ""this is"" followed by the name of the ship initiating the call three times, and ending with ""over.""
answers.c: c) Instruct the nearest public correspondence station to add the desired ship's call sign to the station's traffic list.
answers.d: d) Notify the local vessel traffic service control station of your intention to contact a specific vessel, and request the VTS operator place the call on channel 22A.

question: What is the correct procedure for calling a coast radio station using HF radiotelephone?

answers.a: a) On a properly selected ITU channel, give the name of the coast radio station being called three times, and the words ""this is"" followed by the name of the ship initiating the call three times, and ending with ""over"".
answers.b: b) Contact the nearest U.S.C.G. station to add the desired ship's call sign to the station's traffic list.
answers.c: c) On a correct ITU channel, give the call sign of the coast radio station three times using the ICAO alphabet, the words ""this is"", followed by the ship's call sign three times using the ICAO alphabet and ending with ""over"".
answers.d: d) Request the VTS operator place the call on channel 22A.

question: Which statement is correct regarding HF NBDP under GMDSS?

answers.d: d) SITOR communications can be used to contact a NAVTEX transmitting station when requesting a repeat transmission of a missed NAVTEX message.

question: What statement is true regarding the exchange between two parties engaged in SITOR communications?

answers.a: a) In ARQ, each character is transmitted twice, with the second displaced in time from the first.
answers.b: b) In ARQ, the ""sending"" station transmits a block of three characters and the ""receiving"" station responds with a one character Repeat Request.  Following this the ""transmitting"" station will send a new block.
answers.c: c) In ARQ, the ISS transmits a block of 3 characters and the IRS checks for parity. If the received block is correct a one-character control signal is sent notifying the ISS to proceed with the next block. If the parity check fails the block must be resent.
answers.d: d) Broadcasts of Marine Safety Information, traffic lists, etc. can be copied by the receiving station in ARQ mode.

question: Of the following, which is true of SITOR ARQ mode direct printing radioteletype transmission?

answers.a: a) Each data block consists of three characters.
answers.b: b) The acceptance code consists of three characters.
answers.c: c) A continuous data stream is transmitted.
answers.d: d) Forward error correction reduces the number of errors.

question: Which of the following is true of SITOR ARQ mode?

answers.a: a) This is an interactive mode.
answers.b: b) Each character is repeated three times.
answers.c: c) Each character is transmitted twice.
answers.d: d) This mode is generally used to broadcast messages.

question: In ARQ, when the information sending station (ISS) receives a signal that the parity check failed what happens?

answers.a: a) The last block will be resent.
answers.b: b) The next block will be sent.
answers.c: c) The data link will break.
answers.d: d) The acknowledge light should illuminate.

question: Which of the following is true of SITOR ARQ mode:

answers.a: a) The ship station sends a group of 3 characters twice and then waits for an ""RQ"" signal to indicate proper receipt before continuing transmission.
answers.b: b) The Ship station sends each character twice, using a time diversity system to ensure proper parity.
answers.c: c) The ship station sends a group of 3 characters, the shore station checks for proper parity and then requests the same group be resent to enable error correction.
answers.d: d) The ship station sends a group of 3 characters, the shore station checks for proper parity. If parity is OK, the shore station indicates readiness for transmission of the next 3 characters.

question: Which of the following keystrokes or characters is sent as part of ARQ communications to request a direct TELEX call to a shore-based location?

answers.a: a) MSG+
answers.b: b) GA+?
answers.c: c) ENTER

question: The DIRTLX command should be given to a coast station at what point in time?

answers.a: a) Immediately following the automatic exchange of answerbacks.
answers.b: b) After receipt of the Go Ahead indication followed by the automatic exchange of answerbacks.
answers.c: c) Sent at the beginning of the message to request a direct TELEX connection.
answers.d: d) After receipt of the Go Ahead indication following the automatic exchange of answerbacks.

question: Which automatic TELEX command should be sent by a ship station during SITOR operations to properly address a weather report to the national weather authority?

answers.a: a) WX+ followed by the text of the report.
answers.b: b) OBS+
answers.c: c) OBS+ then MSG+ to indicate weather report.

question: Which of the following would be a valid automatic TELEX code and number for a request for a real-time TELEX connection to a shore-based TELEX terminal?

answers.b: b) DIRTLX then waits for MSG+ to dial 023419645+.
answers.d: d) DIRTLX followed by GA+? and the TELEX number.

question: When requesting a direct TELEX connection to a vessel's Inmarsat-B terminal, (i.e. making a SITOR call to an Inmarsat-B unit) the GMDSS operator must:

answers.a: a) DIRTLX, 00, Ocean Area Code, TELEX number, +.
answers.b: b) DIRTLX, 0, Ocean Area Code, TELEX number, +.
answers.c: c) DIRTLX, 0, Country code, TELEX number, +.

question: To correctly address a SITOR message and transmit it ""live"" to a shore-based office the GMDSS operator would dial which sequence:
Which of the following statements concerning SITOR communications is true?

answers.a: a) Communication is established on the working channel and answerbacks are exchanged before FEC broadcasts can be received.
answers.b: b) Two-way communication with the coast radio station using FEC is not necessary to be able to receive the broadcasts.
answers.c: c) Weather broadcasts cannot be made in FEC because sending each character twice would cause the broadcast to be prohibitively long.

question: Which of the following is true of SITOR Mode B (FEC), in the presence of static crashes.

answers.a: a) Data flow rate depends on signal propagation.
answers.b: b) Idle characters are sent upon request.
answers.c: c) Transmitter and receiver cannot synchronize.
answers.d: d) FEC reduces the error rate by transmitting each character twice.

question: Which of the following statements concerning SITOR communications is true?

answers.a: a) FEC requests are first acknowledged by the vessel's transmitter before broadcasts can be received.
answers.b: b) FEC mode broadcasts can be received without the transmitter being turned on.
answers.c: c) Weather broadcasts are always made in ARQ mode to ensure reception.

question: The sequence ARQ, FEC, SFEC best corresponds to which of the following sequences?

answers.a: a) One-way communications to a single station, one-way communications to all stations, two-way communications.
answers.b: b) One-way communications to all stations, two-way communications, one-way communications to a single station.
answers.c: c) Two way communications, one-way communications to all stations, one-way communications to a single station.
answers.d: d) Two way communications, One way communications to a single station, One way communications to all stations.

question: The sequence BFEC, SFEC, ARQ best corresponds to which of the following sequences?

answers.a: a) One-way communications to a single station, one-way communications to all stations, two-way communications.
answers.b: b) One-way communications to all stations, two way communications, one-way communications to a single station.
answers.c: c) Two way communications, one-way communications to all stations, two-way communications.

question: Selective FEC communications (SFEC) are employed when:

answers.a: a) Multiple stations without a group SELCALL must receive communications without using their transmitters (Radio Silence).
answers.b: b) Multiple stations must receive communications by using their transmitters to achieve phasing.
answers.c: c) An individual station must receive communications without using any transmitters (Radio Silence).
answers.d: d) An individual station must receive communications by using their transmitter to achieve phasing and block other stations from breaking in.

question: If the vessel is within range of NAVTEX broadcasts and both the Inmarsat-C and the NAVTEX receiver are inoperative the GMDSS operator should:

answers.a: a) Select 518 kHz ARQ TELEX on the MF/HF console to receive MSI.
answers.b: b) Request repairs of the Sat-C system and wait until within range of NAVTEX.
answers.c: c) Select an HF MSI frequency and ARQ TELEX mode to receive MSI.
answers.d: d) Select 518 kHz FEC TELEX on the MF/HF console to receive MSI.

question: If the vessel is beyond range of NAVTEX broadcasts and the Sat-C system fails, the GMDSS operator must:

answers.a: a) Select 518 kHz ARQ TELEX on the MF/HF console to receive MSI.
answers.b: b) Request repairs of the Sat-C system and wait until within range of NAVTEX.
answers.c: c) Select an HF MSI frequency and FEC TELEX mode to receive MSI.
answers.d: d) Select 518 kHz FEC TELEX on the MF/HF console to receive MSI.

question: If the vessel is experiencing atmospheric interference with NAVTEX broadcasts, especially in the tropics, the GMDSS operator should:

answers.a: a) Select one of the 6 HF MSI frequencies and set-up the transceiver in ARQ TELEX mode.
answers.b: b) Select one of the 6 MF MSI frequencies and set-up the transceiver in FEC TELEX mode.
answers.c: c) Select one of the 8 HF MSI frequencies and set-up the transceiver in FEC TELEX mode.
answers.d: d) Select the MF MSI frequency dedicated to tropical MSI and set-up the transceiver in FEC TELEX mode.

question: Why must the GMDSS operator be able to set-up FEC & ARQ modes and differentiate between them?

answers.a: a) The proper mode must be selected for reception of HF MSI.
answers.b: b) The proper mode must be selected for follow-on TELEX communications in a Distress situation.
answers.c: c) The ARQ TELEX mode must be selected for follow-on TELEX communications in a Distress situation and the FEC TELEX mode selected for reception of HF MSI.
answers.d: d) Both a) and b) are correct

question: FEC SITOR transmissions might be used to?

answers.a: a) Receive Coast station traffic lists, NAVTEX and VHF MSI broadcasts.
answers.b: b) Send and receive Distress TELEX communications, receive HF MSI and NAVTEX.
answers.c: c) Receive weather messages or Coast Station traffic lists.
answers.d: d) Either b) or c) might be possible

question: FEC NBDP transmissions are normally used to?

answers.a: a) Receive Coast station traffic lists, NAVTEX and VHF MSI broadcasts.
answers.b: b) Receive HF MSI and NAVTEX.
answers.c: c) Receive weather messages, Coast Station traffic lists and company messages.

question: The ""short rules"" of propagation necessary to select the appropriate frequency band are:

answers.a: a) Shorter distance = Higher Frequency, Daytime = Higher Frequency.
answers.b: b) Shorter distance = Higher Frequency, Daytime = Lower Frequency.
answers.c: c) Shorter distance = Lower Frequency, Daytime = Higher Frequency.
answers.d: d) Shorter distance = Lower Frequency, Daytime = Lower Frequency.

question: GMDSS operators should learn which of the following propagation ""rules of thumb""?

answers.a: a) Longer distance = lower frequency, Shorter distance = higher frequency; Daytime = higher frequency, nighttime = lower frequency.
answers.b: b) Longer distance = lower frequency, Shorter distance = lower frequency, Daytime = lower frequency, nighttime = higher frequency.
answers.c: c) Longer distance = higher frequency, Shorter distance = lower frequency, Daytime = higher frequency, nighttime = lower frequency.
answers.d: d) Longer distance = higher frequency, Shorter distance = higher frequency, Daytime = lower frequency, nighttime = higher frequency.

question: What would be the most appropriate HF bands for communicating from San Francisco to Taiwan or the Philippines?

answers.a: a) 16 or 22 MHz when daylight at each end and 8 MHz when dark at each end.
answers.b: b) 12 MHz during daylight at each end and 2 MHz when dark at each end.
answers.c: c) 8 MHz during daylight hours and 16 MHz during darkness.
answers.d: d) 6 MHz during daylight hours and 8 MHz during darkness.

question: GMDSS operators should routinely focus on the factors affecting propagation in what priority?

answers.a: a) Distance & time of day, seasonal variations, sunspot cycle, solar flare alerts.
answers.b: b) Sunspot cycle, distance & time of day, seasonal variations, solar flare alerts.
answers.c: c) Solar flare alerts, distance & time of day, sunspot cycle, seasonal variations.
answers.d: d) Solar flare alerts, sunspot cycle, seasonal variations, distance & time of day.

question: Which statement concerning frequency band selection and propagation most corresponds with standard practice.

answers.a: a) Maximum Usable Frequency (MUF) and Optimum Usable Frequency (OUF) should be calculated prior to setting up the transceiver.
answers.b: b) Propagation rules, Sunspot cycle status and seasonal variations (winter & summer) must always be employed to calculate the proper band selection.
answers.c: c) Propagation ""rules of thumb"" are usually sufficient for routine operations.
answers.d: d) Propagation ""rules of thumb"" should be combined with Solar flare alerts to determine band selection.

question: To ensure effective communications, GMDSS operators should:

answers.a: a) Rely on the equipment calculations of Optimum Usable Frequency.
answers.b: b) Employ the short rules of propagation selection.
answers.c: c) Rely on previous successful communications on the selected frequency band.
answers.d: d) Taken together, both b) and c) are good operational practices.

question: A ship has been communicating effectively on 16 MHz during daylight hours with a shore station at a distance of 3500 miles. Toward late afternoon and evening what effect would be noticed?

answers.a: a) Communications should be maintained with slight improvement in the signal received from the shore station.
answers.b: b) The gray line effect will prevent communications after dark.
answers.c: c) Communications should gradually deteriorate and become impossible on this frequency at night.
answers.d: d) Communications should improve and peak at night.

question: A ship at anchor has been communicating marginally with a shore station approximately 200 miles  distant on a frequency in the 4 MHz band periodically throughout the day. Toward the late afternoon and evening, what effect should be noticed?

answers.a: a) Communications should be maintained with slight improvement in the signal received from the shore station.
answers.b: b) Communications should slowly deteriorate but may be continued throughout the night.
answers.c: c) Communications should gradually deteriorate and become impossible on this frequency by night.
answers.d: d) Communications should gradually improve and peak at night and early morning.

question: At mid-day in the summer, what would be the best choice in attempting to communicate, using NBDP with a shore station some 1800 miles distant?

answers.a: a) VHF-FM
answers.b: b) Higher HF bands
answers.c: c) Lower HF bands

question: At mid-night, what would be the best choice in attempting to communicate, using NBDP with a shore station some 800 miles distant?

answers.a: a) VHF-FM
answers.b: b) Higher UHF bands
answers.c: c) HF bands
answers.d: d) Communications are impossible at this distance.

question: At mid-day, what would be the best choice in attempting to communicate with a shore station some 75 miles distant?

answers.a: a) VHF-FM
answers.b: b) 22 MHz band
answers.c: c) 16 MHz band

question: How can a GMDSS operator determine the best frequency band to choose for a SITOR transmission to a shore station?

answers.a: a) By consulting propagation tables.
answers.b: b) If static interference is present, try lower bands first.
answers.c: c) Listen to shore station ""free signals"" and choose the band with the strongest signal.
answers.d: d) During nighttime, choose higher frequencies. Choose lower frequencies in the daytime.

question: The Distress Alarm sounds and the screen readout no longer contains the particulars of the Distress:

answers.a: a) Examine the printer to determine if the particulars were routed to the printer.
answers.b: b) Examine the Transmitted Data Directory.
answers.c: c) Both a) and d) are correct
answers.d: d) Examine the Received Data Directory.

question: Transmit = 4207.5 kHz and Receive = 4207.5 kHz -- what information can you infer from this?

answers.a: a) The DSC controller decoded the requested voice frequency as 4207.5 kHz simplex and your DSC controller has automatically set-up your transceiver.
answers.b: b) The DSC controller decoded the contents of the DSC call but the request is illegal.
answers.c: c) Both a) and b) are true
answers.d: d) The DSC call came in on 4 MHz DSC. You should set-up your transmitter and respond on the appropriate voice follow-on frequency.

question: You receive an Urgency DSC call to all vessels specifying an alternate TELEX frequency & emission. If your transceiver frequency display reads: 2174.5 kHz transmit & 4207.5 kHz receive:

answers.a: a) Either the call was incorrectly formatted by the other vessel or the other vessel has presumably lost MF/HF voice capability.
answers.b: b) The DSC controller decoded the contents of the DSC call but the request is illegal.
answers.c: c) Both a) and d) are true
answers.d: d) The DSC call came in on 4 MHz DSC but either the call was incorrectly formatted by the other vessel or your controller failed to decode the receive field of the alternate frequency entry and only your Transmit set-up is correct.

question: You receive a Routine DSC call specifying an alternate working voice frequency & emission. Your transceiver frequency display reads: 4125.0 kHz transmit 4125.0 kHz receive:

answers.a: a) The requested alternate working channel was 4125.0 kHz Simplex and your DSC controller has automatically set-up your transceiver.
answers.b: b) The DSC controller decoded the contents of the DSC call and has automatically set-up your transceiver but the request is illegal.
answers.c: c) Both a) and b) are true
answers.d: d) The DSC call came in on 4125 kHz and you should respond on the alternate working frequency.

question: You receive a Routine DSC call to your vessel, without specifying an alternate working voice frequency & emission. Your transceiver frequency display reads: 2177 kHz transmit 2177 kHz receive. What must you do?

answers.a: a) Tune the transmitter and make a voice call to the other vessel on 2187.5 kHz.
answers.b: b) Access the data directory to determine the alternate frequency and then make a voice call to the other vessel on the alternate frequency.
answers.c: c) Manually Acknowledge the DSC call on the alternate frequency, then make a voice call to the other vessel on 2182.0 kHz.
answers.d: d) Call other vessel on 2182.0 kHz and shift to a proper working frequency.

question: An incoming DSC Distress Alert on 8414.5 kHz will have what result?

answers.a: a) The DSC controller will emit both an audible and visual alarm.
answers.b: b) The particulars of the alert may be printed out.
answers.c: c) The Distress information contained in the alert will be sent to the data directory.

question: What is the normal voltage of a single lead acid battery cell?

answers.a: a) 2.1 volts
answers.b: b) 1.5 volts
answers.c: c) 2.5 volts

question: What is the normal specific gravity of a fully charged lead acid battery cell?
What instrument is used for measuring the electrolyte of a lead acid battery?

answers.a: a) Hygrometer
answers.b: b) Hydrometer
answers.c: c) ph Meter

question: What will cause an individual battery cell to reverse polarity.

answers.a: a) High discharge rates without allowing for a cool down period.
answers.b: b) Insufficient charging which does not bring all of the cells up to full charge.
answers.c: c) When discharging the battery string if a cell becomes weaker than the remaining cells, the discharge current will effectively charge the weaker cell in reverse polarity.

question: What is the effect of temperature on the specific gravity of lead acid batteries?

answers.a: a) Higher temperature results in a higher specific gravity reading.
answers.b: b) Temperature has no effect on the specific gravity reading.
answers.c: c) Lower temperature results in a lower specific gravity reading.
answers.d: d) Higher temperature results in a lower specific gravity reading.

question: What would be an indication of a malfunction on a GMDSS station with a 24 VDC battery system?

answers.a: a) A constant 30 volt reading on the GMDSS console voltmeter.
answers.b: b) After testing the station on battery power, the ammeter reading indicates a high rate of charge that then declines.
answers.c: c) After testing the station on battery power, a voltmeter reading of 30 volts for brief period followed by a steady 26 volt reading.

question: Which of the following conditions would be a symptom of malfunction in a 2182 kHz radiotelephone system which must be reported to an onboard or at-sea maintainer under GMDSS?

answers.a: a) Much higher noise level observed during daytime operation.
answers.b: b) No indication of power output when speaking into the microphone.
answers.c: c) When testing a radiotelephone alarm on 2182 kHz into an artificial antenna, the Distress frequency watch receiver becomes unmuted, an improper testing procedure.
answers.d: d) Failure to contact a shore station 600 nautical miles distant during daytime operation.

question: Which would indicate a malfunction in a 2182 kHz radiotelephone system?

answers.a: a) No discernable traffic has been heard on the 2182 kHz during the radiotelephone silent periods.
answers.b: b) Failure to contact another station 60 miles distant during daytime operation.
answers.c: c) Dramatic decrease in noise level observed during night and early morning hours.
answers.d: d) The visual indication of power to the antenna fluctuates while testing the radiotelephone alarm signal generator into an artificial antenna.

question: Which would indicate proper operation of a SSB transmitter rated at 60 Watt PEP output in J3E mode?

answers.a: a) In SITOR communications, the power meter can be seen fluctuating regularly from zero to the 60 watt relative output reading.
answers.b: b) In SSB (J3E) voice mode, with the transmitter keyed but without speaking into the microphone, no power output is indicated.
answers.c: c) In SSB (J3E) mode, speaking into the microphone causes the power meter to fluctuate well above the 60 watt reading.
answers.d: d) A steady indication of transmitted energy on an RF power meter with no fluctuations when speaking into the microphone.

question: Which would be an indication of proper operation of a SSB transmitter rated at 60 watt PEP output?

answers.a: a) In SITOR communications, the power meter can be seen fluctuating regularly from zero to the 60 watt relative output reading.
answers.b: b) In SSB (J3E) voice mode, with the transmitter keyed but without speaking into the microphone, power output is indicated.
answers.c: c) In SSB (J3E) mode, speaking into the microphone causes power meter to fluctuate slightly around the 60 watt reading.
answers.d: d) A steady indication of transmitted energy on an RF Power meter with no fluctuations when speaking into the microphone.

question: Your antenna tuner becomes totally inoperative. What would you do to obtain operation on 2 HF bands?

answers.a: a) Without an operating antenna tuner, transmission is impossible.
answers.b: b) It is impossible to obtain operation on 2 different HF bands, without an operating antenna tuner.
answers.c: c) Bypass the antenna tuner and shorten the whip to 15 ft.
answers.d: d) Bypass the antenna tuner. Use a straight whip or wire antenna approximately 30 ft long.

question: Your MF-HF whip antenna breaks off and is carried away in a storm. What would you do to regain operation on MF-HF frequencies?

answers.a: a) Rig a wire antenna 10-15 ft long from the antenna tuner to the highest vertical support.
answers.b: b) Rig a horizontal, center-fed dipole antenna 40 ft long.
answers.c: c) Rig a wire antenna approximately 35-75 ft long per the equipment instruction manual.
answers.d: d) Rig a long wire antenna at least 200 ft long.
